deck.name: Condition Cards
entries: These cards describe various conditions that can affect creatures in the game. A player whose character is suffering from a condition can keep the card as a reminder, giving it back to you when the condition ends for that character; {@note either physically with the {@adventure printed copies|DIP|18}, or in a VTT.}

deck.name: Condition Cards
entries: {@note These double-sided cards can be used to track conditions by your players; either physically with the {@book printed copies|ScreenDungeonKit|1}, or in a VTT.}

deck.name: Deck of Illusions
cards: Knight and Four Guards|Deck of Illusions|DMG
Archmage and Mage Apprentice|Deck of Illusions|DMG
Priest and Two Acolytes|Deck of Illusions|DMG
Bandit Captain and Three Bandits|Deck of Illusions|DMG
entries: This box contains a set of parchment cards. A full deck has 34 cards. A deck found as treasure is usually missing {@dice 1d20 - 1} cards.

The magic of the deck functions only if cards are drawn at random (you can use an altered deck of playing cards to simulate the deck). You can use an action to draw a card at random from the deck and throw it to the ground at a point within 30 feet of you.

An illusion of one or more creatures forms over the thrown card and remains until dispelled. An illusory creature appears real, of the appropriate size, and behaves as if it were a real creature, except that it can do no harm. While you are within 120 feet of the illusory creature and can see it, you can use an action to move it magically anywhere within 30 feet of its card. Any physical interaction with the illusory creature reveals it to be an illusion, because objects pass through it. Someone who uses an action to visually inspect the creature identifies it as illusory with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. The creature then appears translucent.
The illusion lasts until its card is moved or the illusion is dispelled. When the illusion ends, the image on its card disappears, and that card can't be used again.

deck.name: Deck of Illusions
entries: This box contains a set of cards. A full deck has 34 cards: 32 depicting specific creatures and two with a mirrored surface. A deck found as treasure is usually missing {@dice 1d20 - 1} cards.

The magic of the deck functions only if its cards are drawn at random. You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to draw a card at random from the deck and throw it to the ground at a point within 30 feet of yourself. An illusion of a creature, determined by rolling on the Deck of Illusions table, forms over the thrown card and remains until dispelled. The illusory creature created by the card looks and behaves like a real creature of its kind, except that it can do no harm. While you are within 120 feet of the illusory creature and can see it, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to move it anywhere within 30 feet of its card.

Any physical interaction with the illusory creature reveals it to be false, because objects pass through it. A creature that takes a {@action Study|XPHB} action to visually inspect the illusory creature identifies it as an illusion with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check. The illusion lasts until its card is moved or the illusion is dispelled (using a {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} spell or a similar effect). When the illusion ends, the image on its card disappears, and that card can't be used again.

deck.name: Deck of Many More Things
entries: Over the centuries since the first {@item Deck of Many Things} was created, many have sought and failed to replicate it. But some have created new cards. These forty-four additional cards are known collectively as the Deck of Many More Things. (More information on creating new cards for this deck appears in {@book chapter 2|BMT|1}.)

Like the {@item Deck of Many Things}, the Deck of Many More Things manifests differently on various worlds. While it can include fewer or different cards, it frequently appears with a {@item Deck of Many Things} as part of a combined deck of sixty-six illuminated cards. The combined deck is usually protected by a box or pouch. The forty-four cards of the Deck of Many More Things bear similar imagery to those in the Deck of Many Things and have potent magical effects, which are detailed later in this description. Notably, cards from the Deck of Many More Things are more likely to be beneficial, though about a third of them are still dangerous.

Before you draw a card, you must declare how many cards you intend to draw and then draw them randomly. Unless a card allows you to draw additional cards, any cards drawn exceeding this number have no effect.

As soon as you draw a card, its magic takes effect. You must draw each card you declared no more than 1 hour after the previous draw. Unless a card states otherwise, if you fail to draw the chosen number, the remaining number of cards fly from the deck and take effect simultaneously.

Unless it is the {@card Fool|Deck of Many More Things|BMT} or the {@card Jester|Deck of Many More Things|BMT} card, a drawn card immediately takes effect, fades from existence, and reappears in the deck, making it possible to draw the same card multiple times.

The DM can use the physical cards provided in The Deck of Many Things card set to build a combined Deck of Many Things and Deck of Many More Things, including whichever cards they desire. Alternatively, roll on the Deck of Many More Things table below to randomly determine what cards are drawn.

entries.caption: Deck of Many More Things
footnotes: * Found in the {@item Deck of Many Things} as depicted in the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}

deck.name: Deck of Many More Things
entries: The following pages describe the meanings of the sixty-six cards in The {@deck Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG|Deck of Many Things} card set. For each card, there's an illustration and a description of the symbols depicted, a summary of the card's overall meaning, and explanations of what the card might signify in both upright and reversed (upside-down) positions. Each position includes five possible signifiers to choose from based on the situation:

items: A {@b person}, with suggestions regarding personality traits or the situation the person is in. A person can be any kind of Humanoid, but might also be a Giant, a Dragon, or any other creature with a personality and the ability to interact with characters. This signifier might also describe something about the person for whom a card reading is being done.
A {@b creature or trap} characters might encounter.
A {@b place}, which can suggest a specific location or a kind of location.
A {@b treasure}, either something of monetary value or a magic item.
A {@b situation}—an interaction or circumstance that characters might be asked to help address.

entries: When using the cards for divinatory readings, you can use cards' overall meaning or draw on any signifiers that make sense for your game. The adventure spreads typically draw on all five kinds of signifiers to build the skeleton of an adventure.

entries: {@style DUNGEONS & DRAGONS|dnd-font} is about far more than monsters or treasure; it's built on a foundation of community, friendship, and imagination—just like a good meal. In this {@i Heroes' Feast: The Deck of Many Morsels}, you will find a curated selection of uniquely D&D recipes, which span the vast multiverse; these were previously only available to your in-game characters. They are all delicious, easy to prepare, and comprise ingredients readily found in this realm. Even better, these snack and drink recipes offer a unique opportunity to enhance the social experience that is D&D, whether it happens to be a game night, or you just wish it were.

However, a word of caution to all who wield this item. It is a deck of power, a deck of might, a deck of unabashed flavor not to be trifled (or truffled) with. Use it carefully and may the dice be good to you!

deck.name: Deck of Many Things
entries: A {@item Deck of Many Things} typically appears not as individual cards, but as a collection of cards characters can draw from. But this doesn't have to be true; you can give each card a property as a standalone item, so characters who find only one card can still enjoy this famed item and use the card on adventures.

This approach is particularly useful if you make a {@item Deck of Many Things} the object of a quest; as the characters explore, each card they find grants them a magical ability they can use in subsequent adventures to find the cards that remain. Eventually the heroes assemble the entire deck, which they can then use in the traditional manner, drawing transformative cards from it in a fitting climax to the campaign.
You can grant the following additional magical properties to the cards of the {@item Deck of Many Things}:

deck.name: Deck of Many Things
entries: Usually found in a box or pouch, this deck contains a number of cards made of ivory or vellum. Most ({@chance 75}) of these decks have only thirteen cards, but the rest have twenty-two.

Before you draw a card, you must declare how many cards you intend to draw and then draw them randomly (you can use an altered deck of playing cards to simulate the deck). Any cards drawn in excess of this number have no effect. Otherwise, as soon as you draw a card from the deck, its magic takes effect. You must draw each card no more than 1 hour after the previous draw. If you fail to draw the chosen number, the remaining number of cards fly from the deck on their own and take effect all at once.

Once a card is drawn, it fades from existence. Unless the card is the {@card Fool|Deck of Many Things} or the {@card Jester|Deck of Many Things}, the card reappears in the deck, making it possible to draw the same card twice.

entries.name: A Question of Enmity
entries: Two of the cards in a deck of many things can earn a character the enmity of another being. With the {@card Flames|Deck of Many Things} card, the enmity is overt. The character should experience the devil's malevolent efforts on multiple occasions. Seeking out the fiend shouldn't be a simple task, and the adventurer should clash with the devil's allies and followers a few times before being able to confront the devil itself.

In the case of the {@card Rogue|Deck of Many Things} card, the enmity is secret and should come from someone thought to be a friend or an ally. As Dungeon Master, you should wait for a dramatically appropriate moment to reveal this enmity, leaving the adventurer guessing who is likely to become a betrayer.

footnotes: * Found only in a deck with twenty-two cards

deck.name: Deck of Many Things
entries: Usually found in a box or pouch, this deck contains a number of cards made of ivory or vellum. Most (75 percent) of these decks have thirteen cards, but some have twenty-two. Use the appropriate column of the Deck of Many Things table when randomly determining cards drawn from the deck.

Before you draw a card, you must declare how many cards you intend to draw and then draw them randomly. Any cards drawn in excess of this number have no effect. Otherwise, as soon as you draw a card from the deck, its magic takes effect. You must draw each card no more than 1 hour after the previous draw. If you fail to draw the chosen number, the remaining number of cards fly from the deck on their own and take effect all at once.

Once a card is drawn, it disappears. Unless the card is the Fool or Jester, the card reappears in the deck, making it possible to draw the same card twice. (Once the Fool or Jester has left the deck, reroll on the table if that card comes up again.)

deck.name: Deck of Several Things
entries: Stored in a leather pouch, this unique deck contains twenty-two colored cards made of some strong but unknown metal, each of which features a design printed as a mosaic of raised dots. Before you draw a card, you must declare how many cards you intend to draw and then draw them randomly (you can use an altered deck of playing cards to simulate the deck). Any cards drawn in excess of this number have no effect. Otherwise, as soon as you draw a card from the deck, its magic takes effect. You must draw each card no more than 1 hour after the previous draw. If you fail to draw the chosen number, the remaining number of cards fly from the deck on their own and take effect all at once.

Once a card is drawn, it fades from existence. Unless the card is the {@card Fool|Deck of Several Things|LLK} or the {@card Jester|Deck of Several Things|LLK}, the card reappears in the deck, making it possible to draw the same card twice.

entries.name: Using the Deck of Several Things
entries: The special nature of this deck (carried by {@creature Mary Greymalkin|LLK} if she is used as an NPC) means that many of its effects operate only within and with respect to this specific adventure. This typically covers any time the characters spend between setting out for the Barrier Peaks and the resolution of whatever events transpire in Kwalish's lab (area O7).

For cards that effectively remove a character from play for a period of time ({@card Donjon|Deck of Several Things|LLK} and {@card the Void|Deck of Several Things|LLK}), you can allow a player to take on the role of one of the party's NPC hirelings, or introduce a temporary character as an NPC met during the party's journey. Alternatively, you can decide that only some aspect of the character's will disappears and is imprisoned, leaving the character to operate in a robotic state until freed.

deck.name: Deck of Wonder
entries: Created in the image of the Deck of Many Things, this deck of ivory or vellum cards bestows an assortment of minor benefits and penalties on those who draw from it. Most (75 percent) of these decks have only thirteen cards, but the rest have twenty-two.

Before you draw a card, you must declare how many cards you intend to draw, then draw them randomly. Any additional cards drawn have no effect. Unless a card states otherwise, as soon as you draw a card from the deck, its magic takes effect. You must draw each card you declared no more than 1 hour after the previous draw. If you fail to draw the chosen number, the remaining number of cards fly from the deck and take effect simultaneously.
Unless it is the Mystery card, a drawn card immediately takes effect, fades from existence, and reappears in the deck, making it possible to draw the same card multiple times.
You can use an altered deck of playing cards to simulate the deck, as shown in the Deck of Wonder table.

deck.name: Elder Runes Deck
entries: Elder runes are ancient symbols imbued with magical power. With years of study, any creature that can cast the {@spell symbol} spell can learn an elder rune and add it to the selection of symbols that can be created with the spell. Halaster has spent lifetimes studying elder runes, inventing new ones, and harnessing their volatile magic. He likes to place them throughout Undermountain as hazards.

{@adventure Appendix B|WDMM|26} presents several {@deck elder runes deck|WDMM|elder runes on paper cards} that you can photocopy and cut out to create an {@deck Elder Runes Deck|WDMM}. When circumstances call for the appearance of an elder rune, a card is drawn from this deck to determine which rune appears and what it does.
Elder runes function as symbols cast using the {@spell symbol} spell, with these changes:

items: An elder rune has two possible effects: one beneficial (called the boon effect) and the other harmful (called the bane effect). The elder rune's creator chooses which effect occurs or can randomize it so that a die is rolled to determine whether the bane effect (odd die roll) or the boon effect (even die roll) is triggered.
A triggered elder rune targets one or more creatures within 60 feet of it, according to the caster's specifications. Once the effect activates, the elder rune disappears and the spell ends.

entries: A creature doesn't make a saving throw against an elder rune's boon effect. Saving throws made to resist the bane effect of Halaster's elder rune have a spell save DC of 22.
{@note Printable assets are available {@adventure here.|WDMM|26}}

deck.name: Features Deck
entries: A dungeon spread is a simpler version of an adventure spread that's optimized for quickly building dungeon-focused adventures. In this variant, you divide The {@deck Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG|Deck of Many Things} card set into three separate decks: a locations deck, a features deck, and an optional story deck. For simplicity, use the literal meanings of the cards in the locations and features decks; these cards are straightforward descriptions of potential locations and of the creatures, treasures, and other features characters might find in these locations.

If you want to create a prelude to the dungeon, use the optional steps that call for the story deck, and give those cards their full range of symbolic meaning as discussed in the "{@book Reading the Cards|DMTCRG|3}" section. If you'd rather dive straight into the action, you can skip those steps and omit the story deck.

deck.name: Fragments of Suffering
entries: The cards in {@adventure appendix D|CRCotN|11} are meant to be given to players whose characters gain {@deck Fragments of Suffering|CRCotN} in {@adventure chapter 6|CRCotN|6} (see that chapter for more information).
{@note Printable assets are available in {@adventure Appendix D.|CRCotN|11}}

deck.name: Geomorph Cards
entries: {@note These cards can be used to plan a dungeon during game preparation or come up with a map in the middle of play; either physically with the {@book printed copies|ScreenDungeonKit|1}, or in a VTT.}

deck.name: Hazard Cards
entries: {@note These double-sided cards can be used to track hazards your players have encountered; either physically with the {@book printed copies|ScreenDungeonKit|1}, or in a VTT.}

deck.name: Initiative Cards
entries: After the characters and each group of monsters involved in a combat roll initiative, distribute these cards among the combat participants, from the highest to lowest initiative count. For example, whoever rolls the highest initiative gets the "1" card and acts first, whoever rolls the second highest initiative gets the "2" card, and so on. Keep the numbered cards for the creatures you're running.
{@note Printable assets are available {@adventure here.|DIP|18}}

deck.name: Initiative Cards
entries: {@note These cards can be used to track initiative order; either physically with the {@book printed copies|ScreenDungeonKit|1}, or in a VTT.}

deck.name: Locations Deck
entries: A dungeon spread is a simpler version of an adventure spread that's optimized for quickly building dungeon-focused adventures. In this variant, you divide The {@deck Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG|Deck of Many Things} card set into three separate decks: a locations deck, a features deck, and an optional story deck. For simplicity, use the literal meanings of the cards in the locations and features decks; these cards are straightforward descriptions of potential locations and of the creatures, treasures, and other features characters might find in these locations.

If you want to create a prelude to the dungeon, use the optional steps that call for the story deck, and give those cards their full range of symbolic meaning as discussed in the "{@book Reading the Cards|DMTCRG|3}" section. If you'd rather dive straight into the action, you can skip those steps and omit the story deck.

deck.name: Magic Charm Cards

entries: This card describes a special charm. Give the card to the player whose character receives the charm. Collect the card when the charm ends for that character.
{@note Printable assets are available {@adventure here.|DIP|18}}

deck.name: Quest Cards
entries: When a new quest becomes available to the characters, give that quest's card to the players. Collect the card if the characters complete the quest or decide they don't want to complete it.
{@note Printable assets are available {@adventure here.|DIP|18}}

deck.name: Roleplaying Cards
cards: Sir Talavar the Faerie Dragon|Roleplaying Cards|WBtW
entries: The following pages provide easy-to-use versions of {@adventure Appendix D|WBtW|9} from {@adventure The Wild Beyond the Witchlight|WBtW}.
{@note See the appendices for printable assets.}

deck.name: Secrets Deck
cards: Gith Who's Coming to Dinner?|Secrets Deck|WDMM
entries: {@adventure Appendix C|WDMM|27} of this book contains the {@deck Secrets Deck|WDMM}—paper cards for you to photocopy and hand out to the players when their characters learn reliable information about Halaster and Undermountain.

Any character who spends at least four hours in the Yawning Portal is likely to overhear tall tales about the Mad Mage and his dungeon. Not all rumors are to be believed, however, and characters need keen ears and sharp insight to determine which stories have weight. Have each character make a {@dc 20} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check or Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. If the check succeeds, the character learns a secret about Undermountain, and the player can draw a card from the {@deck Secrets Deck|WDMM}.

Players can hold onto these cards for later reference. When the characters meet an NPC in Undermountain who knows a fact, have one of the players draw another card from the {@deck Secrets Deck|WDMM} to determine what that NPC knows about Halaster and his dungeon.
{@note Printable assets are available {@adventure here.|WDMM|27}}

deck.name: Sidekick Cards
entries: On your adventures, the DM might reveal that you've befriended a special character called a sidekick, who joins your party. This appendix presents the game statistics for sidekicks, of which there are three types:
{@creature Expert|ESK}, an agile and exceedingly helpful jack of all trades
{@creature Spellcaster|ESK}, a magic-user who can cast spells to harm your foes or heal you and your friends
{@creature Warrior|ESK}, a martial companion who specializes in striking your foes or defending you and your allies
The DM will either tell you which type of sidekick to use or let you choose one. It's up to you and the DM to decide who controls the sidekick in play.
{@note Printable assets are available {@adventure here.|DIP|18}}

deck.name: Story Deck
entries: A dungeon spread is a simpler version of an adventure spread that's optimized for quickly building dungeon-focused adventures. In this variant, you divide The {@deck Deck of Many More Things|DMTCRG|Deck of Many Things} card set into three separate decks: a locations deck, a features deck, and an optional story deck. For simplicity, use the literal meanings of the cards in the locations and features decks; these cards are straightforward descriptions of potential locations and of the creatures, treasures, and other features characters might find in these locations.

If you want to create a prelude to the dungeon, use the optional steps that call for the story deck, and give those cards their full range of symbolic meaning as discussed in the "{@book Reading the Cards|DMTCRG|3}" section. If you'd rather dive straight into the action, you can skip those steps and omit the story deck.

deck.name: Tarokka Deck
entries: {@note The rules for {@variantrule Prophet's Gambit|CoS} are available here.}
The Vistani have long been masters of fortune-telling. In the hands of a Vistani seer, a deck of tarokka cards can tell tales of the future and provide answers to many a dark and mysterious question.

Although the workmanship and artistic quality of the cards can vary from deck to deck, the ability of the cards to call forth information about the future is far more valuable than the monetary worth of a deck.

Anyone can craft a deck of tarokka cards, but only someone of Vistani blood can imbue the cards with the gift of prophecy. Once they are crafted and empowered, they must be stored in accordance with ancient tradition, or they lose their efficacy. When not in use, tarokka cards must be wrapped in silk and stored in a wooden box.

entries.name: Composition
entries: A tarokka deck has fifty-four cards, each of which has its own name. Forty of them comprise the common deck, which is divided into four suits: swords, coins, stars, and glyphs.

Each suit contains cards numbered one through nine, plus a tenth card that is called the master of that suit. A card can be referred to by its suit designation or by its name. For instance, the three of glyphs is also known as the {@card healer|Tarokka Deck|CoS}, and the {@card wizard|Tarokka Deck|CoS} card is also known as the master of stars.
The remaining fourteen cards make up the high deck, which symbolizes the natural forces of the multiverse. These cards are represented by a crown symbol and are the most powerful cards in the deck.

entries.name: High Deck
entries: The cards that compose the high deck aren't considered to be one suit, although they are often denoted with a crown icon to mark their importance. Rather, each card is an important power in its own right. If one of these cards comes out in a casting and seems to contradict the prediction of an earlier card, the Vistani always assume that this card takes precedence.

entries.name: Common Deck
entries: The four suits and their respective cards are described in more detail below.

entries.name: Swords
entries: This suit symbolizes aggression and violence. It is the suit of warriors, be they paladins, soldiers, mercenaries, or gladiators. It also symbolizes the power of governments and leaders, whether noble or corrupt.

entries.name: Stars
entries: This suit symbolizes the desire for personal power and control over things beyond the ken of mortals. It is the suit of arcane mages, sages, and intellectuals. It also represents the triumph of magic, science, and reason over religion, mysticism, and superstition.

entries.name: Coins
entries: This suit symbolizes avarice and the desire for personal and material gain. It is also symbolic of gluttony, lust, and obsession. On the side of good, this suit can suggest the accumulation of wealth for the benefit of a charity or a just cause. On the side of evil, it embodies the worst aspects of greed. It speaks to the power of gold, and how that power can build or destroy nations.

entries.name: Glyphs
entries: This suit symbolizes faith, spirituality, and inner strength. It is the suit of priests and those who devote themselves to the service of a deity, a higher power, or a heightened philosophy. On the side of good, it represents willpower and dedication. On the side of evil, the suit signifies weakness of character, self-doubt, and betrayal of one's ideals or beliefs. It symbolizes health and healing, as well as illness and disease.

deck.name: Tarot Deck
entries: Traditionally tarot is played by a reader and a seeker, but feel free to switch roles as the reading carries on. To read your own tarot, you take on both the roles of reader and seeker. Most tarot readings start with a question, and the quality of the question will determine the quality of the answer. For example, instead of asking {@i Why am I always sad?} try {@i How do I bring more joy to my life?}

Each card that is revealed adds to the unique tapestry of meaning, helping the seeker make inquiries into their own life and psyche to gain clarity about their current situation and conclude what might be possible for their future.

Although the root meaning of each card is explained in this booklet, the true meaning of each card can only be discovered within the context of the reading, as the cards begin to influence one another to create a story. And so it's best to allow the reading to unfold (five cards is a good number) without trying to define the answer.

entries.name: The Major Arcana,
entries: denoted by the cards numbered from 0 to 21 represent the archetypal life lessons all human beings experience, such as love, loss, change, and consciousness. The Major Arcana are challenges we revisit throughout our lives, but in different places; our life experience is continually expanding with time, so our capacity for understanding gives us a deeper insight into these lessons.

entries.name: The Minor Arcana,
entries: is made of 56 cards divided into four suits. These cards represent life's temporary highs and lows that pop up and fade away, unlike the enduring and evolving transformations of the Major Arcana.
In this tarot deck, we have mapped the traditional suits of the Minor Arcana—Wands, Swords, Cups, and Pentacles—to abilities within the game of D&D.

items.name: Strength
entries: signifies your physical ability to move and change your environment. It is also your passion, creativity, inner resolve, and heart. These cards show seekers that they need to take action and focus on their inner strength to bring about change in the world.

items.name: Intelligence
entries: represents how the power of the intellect can shape our world. These cards show seekers how they can use their thoughts to shape their attitude and their reality. Rarely do we see the world as it is without our mind creating a story around it.

items.name: Wisdom
entries: represents not only your external perception but also your capacity to look into your internal world and see all the subtleties within yourself. These cards tell seekers to turn within and listen to the nonverbal language of the heart and the body in order to gain access to the wisdom of insight and intuition.

items.name: Charisma
entries: denotes a person's confidence, eloquence, and their ability to influence the material world with their energy. These cards show seekers that a flowering of their inner beauty and power is taking place or that they have an opportunity to grow their self- esteem and expand their capacity for fun and joy.

entries.name: Upright and Reversed Meanings
entries: Many tarot readers give upside-down (reversed) cards an opposite meaning of the upright version. In this booklet, there is no reversed meaning, but as the reader of tarot, feel free to follow your intuition. If you feel that the seeker needs a bit of a wake-up call, then a reversed interpretation can often do the trick.

deck.name: Trickster Gods of Omu
entries: {@note See the {@adventure Spirits of the Nine Trickster Gods|ToA|5|Spirits of the Nine Trickster Gods} section for more information.}

items.name: Determine surprise
entries: The DM determines whether anyone involved in the combat encounter is {@status surprised}.

items.name: Establish positions
entries: The DM decides where all the characters and monsters are located. Given the character's marching order and their stated positions, the DM figures out where the adversaries are—how far away and in what direction.

items.name: Roll initiative
entries: Everyone involved rolls initiative, determining the order of combatants' turns.

items.name: Take turns
entries: Each participant in the combat takes a turn in the initiative order.

items.name: Begin the next round
entries: When every participant in the combat has had a turn, the round ends. Repeat step 4 until the fighting stops.

card.name: Adult Red Dragon

card.name: Troll

card.name: Wyvern
entries: This card creates an illusion of a {@creature Wyvern|XMM}.

card.name: Aberration
entries: You gain telepathy within a range of 90 feet.

card.name: Balance
entries: Your mind suffers a wrenching alteration, causing your alignment to change. Lawful becomes chaotic, good becomes evil, and vice versa. If you are true neutral or unaligned, this card has no effect on you.

card.name: Beast
entries: You immediately transform into a {@filter random Beast with a CR of 5 or lower|bestiary|source=|Challenge Rating=[&0;&5]|type=beast}. Your game statistics—including your ability scores, hit points, and possible actions—are replaced by the Beast's game statistics, and any nonmagical equipment you're wearing or carrying melds into your new form and can't be used. Any magic items you're carrying drop in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of your new form.

You remain transformed in this way for {@dice 2d12} days; nothing can alter your form while you're under the effects of this card, but the {@spell Wish} spell can end the transformation early. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the same state you were in when you initially transformed.

card.name: Book
entries: You gain the ability to speak, read, and write {@dice 1d6 + 2} languages of your choice.

card.name: Bridge
entries: You gain the ability to cast the {@spell Time Stop} spell {@dice 1d3} times. Use your Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as the spellcasting ability (your choice).

card.name: Campfire
entries: You immediately gain the benefits of finishing a long rest.

card.name: Cavern
entries: You gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed. You also gain the ability to move up, down, across vertical surfaces, and along ceilings, while leaving your hands free.

card.name: Celestial
entries: You sprout a pair of softly luminescent, feathered wings from your back and gain a flying speed of 30 feet.

card.name: Comet
entries: If you single-handedly defeat the next hostile monster or group of monsters you encounter, you gain experience points enough to gain one level. Otherwise, this card has no effect.

card.name: Construct
entries: A {@creature homunculus} appears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you. The appearance of the homunculus is determined by the DM, and the homunculus treats you as its creator.

card.name: Corpse
entries: You immediately drop to 0 hit points, have the {@condition unconscious} condition, and must begin making death saving throws. Spells and other magical effects that restore hit points have no effect on you until you are stabilized. If you fail three death saving throws, you die and can be resurrected only by the {@spell Wish} spell.

card.name: Crossroads
entries: Roll a {@dice d20}. If the roll is even, you age {@dice 1d10} years. If the roll is odd, you become younger by {@dice 1d10} years, to a minimum of 1 year. This effect can be undone only by the {@spell Wish} spell, divine intervention, or similar magic.

card.name: Donjon
entries: You disappear and become entombed in a state of suspended animation in an extradimensional sphere. Everything you were wearing and carrying stays behind in the space you occupied when you disappeared. You remain imprisoned until you are found and removed from the sphere. You can't be located by any divination magic, but a {@spell wish} spell can reveal the location of your prison. You draw no more cards.

card.name: Door
entries: You gain the ability to cast the {@spell Gate} spell {@dice 1d4} times, requiring no material components. Use your Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as the spellcasting ability (your choice).

card.name: Dragon
entries: A dragon egg appears at your feet and immediately hatches into a dragon wyrmling. The type of dragon is chosen by the DM. The wyrmling views you as its parent and is staunchly loyal to you and your allies.

card.name: Elemental
entries: You become immune to one of the following damage types (choose immediately upon drawing this card): acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder.

card.name: Euryale
entries: The card's {@creature medusa}-like visage curses you. You take a −2 penalty on saving throws while cursed in this way. Only a god or the magic of the {@card Fates|Deck of Many More Things|BMT} card can end this curse.

card.name: Expert
entries: Your Dexterity score increases by 2, to a maximum of 22.

card.name: Fates
entries: Reality's fabric unravels and spins anew, allowing you to avoid or erase one event as if it never happened. You can use the card's magic as soon as you draw the card or at any other time before you die.

card.name: Fey
entries: A fey crossing opens into the Feywild, and you're immediately pulled through it, disappearing in a flash of rainbow-colored light. You draw no more cards.

The fey crossing appears as a shimmering fractal of light above the deck, and it remains open for 1 minute after the card is drawn. The precise location in the Feywild to which the fey crossing leads is determined by the DM.

card.name: Fiend
entries: A powerful Fiend appears in a nearby unoccupied space and offers you a deal. The precise nature of this deal is up to the DM, but usually the Fiend offers some material reward in exchange for you and your allies completing a task for the Fiend. The Fiend is indifferent to you and can be bargained with; it keeps its side of any bargain it makes, though it might twist the wording of any agreement to suit its purposes. If attacked, or if negotiations fail and you refuse the Fiend's offer, it returns to its home plane.

card.name: Flames
entries: A powerful devil becomes your enemy. The devil seeks your ruin and plagues your life, savoring your suffering before attempting to slay you. This enmity lasts until either you or the devil dies.

card.name: Fool
entries: You lose 10,000 XP, discard this card, and draw from the deck again, counting both draws as one of your declared draws. If losing that much XP would cause you to lose a level, you instead lose an amount that leaves you with just enough XP to keep your level.

card.name: Gem
entries: Twenty-five pieces of jewelry worth 2,000 gp each or fifty gems worth 1,000 gp each appear at your feet.

card.name: Giant
entries: You immediately grow {@dice 2d10} inches in height, and your hit point maximum and current hit points both increase by 20.

card.name: Humanoid
entries: You can immediately choose to stop drawing from the deck, regardless of how many cards you initially declared.

card.name: Jester
entries: You gain 10,000 XP, or you can draw two additional cards beyond your declared draws.

card.name: Key
entries: A rare or rarer magic weapon with which you are proficient appears in your hands. The DM chooses the weapon.

card.name: Knight
entries: You gain the service of a 4th-level fighter who appears in a space you choose within 30 feet of you. The fighter is of the same race as you and serves you loyally until death, believing the fates have drawn him or her to you. You control this character.

card.name: Lance
entries: All your ability scores increase by 1, to a maximum of 20.

card.name: Mage
entries: Your Intelligence score increases by 2, to a maximum of 22.

card.name: Map
entries: At any time you choose within 1 year of drawing this card, you can mentally name or describe an object or individual that is familiar to you. You immediately know the location of the object or individual, as well as the distance between you and the object or individual, even if the object or individual is on a different plane of existence. If you named an individual, you know if they are alive and any conditions they have. If you named an object, you know if it is broken or not. If you named a magic item that has charges, you know how many charges it has remaining.

card.name: Maze
entries: You gain {@dice 1d3} levels of {@condition exhaustion}.

card.name: Mine
entries: A pile of {@dice 2d6} gems (each worth 5,000 gp) and {@dice 1d10} chunks of precious ore (each worth 2,500 gp) appears at your feet.

card.name: Monstrosity
entries: A {@filter Large or larger Monstrosity with a challenge rating of 10 or less|bestiary|source=|Challenge Rating=[&0;&10]|type=monstrosity|size=l;h;g} (chosen by the DM) appears in an unoccupied space within 15 feet of you. The creature is hostile toward you and attacks immediately. The creature disappears when it is killed or when you are reduced to 0 hit points. If there isn't enough space for a Large or larger creature to appear, this card has no effect.

card.name: Moon
entries: You are granted the ability to cast the {@spell wish} spell {@dice 1d3} times.

card.name: Ooze
entries: A {@creature gelatinous cube} immediately appears in your space and engulfs you. The gelatinous cube is hostile and remains until it is destroyed. If there isn't enough space for the gelatinous cube to appear, this card has no effect.

card.name: Path
entries: Your walking speed increases by 10 feet.

card.name: Pit
entries: A pit opens beneath you. You plummet {@damage 3d6  10} feet, take damage from the fall, and have the {@condition prone} condition.

card.name: Plant
entries: You gain the ability to cast {@spell Speak with Plants} without using a spell slot; you must finish a long rest before you can cast it this way again. If you have spell slots of 3rd level or higher, you can cast this spell using them. Use your Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as the spellcasting ability (your choice).

card.name: Priest
entries: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, to a maximum of 22.

card.name: Prisoner
entries: Glowing chains made of magical force appear and wrap around you. You have the {@condition restrained} condition until the chains are destroyed or you are freed. While you have this condition, you can't cast spells, and any magic items you're wearing or carrying have their properties suppressed. You draw no more cards. The chains are immune to damage and can't be dispelled using the {@spell Dispel Magic} spell or similar magic. However, a {@spell Disintegrate} spell destroys the chains instantly, freeing you. Another creature can also free you by succeeding on a {@dc 30} Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|PHB}.

card.name: Puzzle
entries: Permanently reduce your Intelligence by {@dice 1d4 + 1} (to a minimum score of 1). You can draw one additional card beyond your declared draws.

card.name: Ring
entries: A {@filter rare or rarer magic ring|items|source=|type=ring|rarity=rare;very rare;legendary;artifact|category=} appears on your finger. If you have the attunement slots available, you're automatically attuned to the ring when it appears. The DM chooses the ring.

card.name: Rogue
entries: A nonplayer character of the DM's choice becomes hostile toward you. The identity of your new enemy isn't known until the NPC or someone else reveals it. Nothing less than a {@spell wish} spell or divine intervention can end the NPC's hostility toward you.

card.name: Ruin
entries: All forms of wealth that you carry or own, other than magic items, are lost to you. Portable property vanishes. Businesses, buildings, and land you own are lost in a way that alters reality the least. Any documentation that proves you should own something lost to this card also disappears.

card.name: Sage
entries: At any time you choose within one year of drawing this card, you can ask a question in meditation and mentally receive a truthful answer to that question. Besides information, the answer helps you solve a puzzling problem or other dilemma. In other words, the knowledge comes with wisdom on how to apply it.

card.name: Shield
entries: A {@filter rare or rarer suit of magic armor|items|source=|type=light armor;heavy armor;medium armor|rarity=rare;very rare;legendary;artifact|category=} that you are proficient with appears in your hands. The DM chooses the armor. If you lack proficiency with any armor, your base AC instead now equals 12 + your Dexterity modifier while you aren't wearing armor.

card.name: Ship
entries: You gain proficiency in three skills chosen by the DM.

card.name: Skull
entries: You summon an {@creature avatar of death|DMG}—a ghostly humanoid skeleton clad in a tattered black robe and carrying a spectral scythe. It appears in a space of the DM's choice within 10 feet of you and attacks you, warning all others that you must win the battle alone. The avatar fights until you die or it drops to 0 hit points, whereupon it disappears. If anyone tries to help you, the helper summons its own {@creature avatar of death|DMG}. A creature slain by an {@creature avatar of death|DMG} can't be restored to life.

card.name: Staff
entries: A {@filter rare or rarer magic rod, staff, or wand|items|source=|type=rod;wand;staff|rarity=rare;very rare;legendary;artifact|category=} appears in your hands. The DM chooses the item.

card.name: Stairway
entries: You can choose to either decrease your number of declared draws by two or receive a {@filter rare or rarer wondrous item|items|source=|type=wondrous item|rarity=rare;very rare;legendary;artifact|category=}, which appears in your hands. The DM chooses the item.

card.name: Star
entries: Increase one of your ability scores by 2. The score can exceed 20 but can't exceed 24.

card.name: Statue
entries: You immediately have the {@condition petrified} condition as your body is transformed into marble. The petrification lasts until you are freed with the {@spell Greater Restoration} spell or similar magic.

card.name: Sun
entries: You gain 50,000 XP, and {@filter a wondrous item|items|source=|type=wondrous item|category=} (which the DM determines randomly) appears in your hands.

card.name: Talons
entries: Every magic item you wear or carry disintegrates. Artifacts in your possession aren't destroyed but do vanish.

card.name: Tavern
entries: Your Charisma score increases by 2 to a maximum of 22.

card.name: Temple
entries: A deity or entity of similar power becomes bound to aid you. At any point in time between drawing the card and when you die, you can use your action to call on this entity for divine intervention, and the entity is bound to answer. The parameters and nature of this intervention are chosen by the DM. If you die without having used this intervention, the deity fulfills its obligation by casting the {@spell Resurrection} spell on you. Once the entity has answered your call for divine intervention or resurrected you, the entity is no longer bound to aid you.

card.name: Throne
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill, and you double your proficiency bonus on checks made with that skill. In addition, you gain rightful ownership of a small keep somewhere in the world. However, the keep is currently in the hands of monsters, which you must clear out before you can claim the keep as yours.

card.name: Tomb
entries: At any time you choose within 1 year of drawing this card, you can cast the {@spell True Resurrection} spell once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. Use your Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as the spellcasting ability (your choice).

card.name: Tower
entries: Draw two additional cards beyond your declared number of draws. The magic of these cards doesn't immediately take effect; instead, choose one of the two additional cards to keep, returning the other to the deck. The magic of the card you keep takes effect immediately thereafter.

card.name: Tree
entries: Your skin immediately becomes rough, like tree bark. Your base AC now equals 15 + your Dexterity modifier while you aren't wearing armor, but you have vulnerability to fire damage. This transformation can be undone only by the {@spell Wish} spell, divine intervention, or similar magic.

card.name: Undead
entries: Somewhere on the Material Plane, a {@creature revenant} rises. This revenant blames you for its existence and relentlessly hunts you to exact its revenge. The revenant exists until either 1 year passes, the revenant kills you, or you use a {@spell Wish} spell to banish it permanently to the afterlife.

card.name: Void
entries: This black card spells disaster. Your soul is drawn from your body and contained in an object in a place of the DM's choice. One or more powerful beings guard the place. While your soul is trapped in this way, your body is {@condition incapacitated}. A {@spell wish} spell can't restore your soul, but the spell reveals the location of the object that holds it. You draw no more cards.

card.name: Warrior
entries: Your Strength score increases by 2 to a maximum of 22.

card.name: Well
entries: You learn three cantrips of your choice from any spell list.

card.name: Aberration
entries: {@i A beholder hovers in a cluttered laboratory. The Aberration card embodies things contrary to nature.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone with a distorted view of reality, perhaps a {@creature cultist} or a {@creature warlock of the Great Old One|MPMM}; perhaps simply an eccentric person with a nonconformist style.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature corrupted by the influence of the Far Realm, or an Aberration.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where the laws of physics or magic are suspended or distorted.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that reflects a warped view of reality, or a magic item made by Aberrations.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An incursion of energy or creatures from the Far Realm or the deep Underdark.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person (perhaps a {@creature druid}) dedicated to preserving nature against corrupting influences.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that has resisted the corruption of its nature, or a trap that deals psychic damage.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where nature has overgrown the remnants of a corrupting influence.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the triumph of nature over corruption, or a magic item useful against Aberrations (such as a {@item Ring of Mind Shielding}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: People or creatures fighting against the influence of Aberrations.

card.name: Balance
entries: {@i A set of scales holds day and night in balance. This card deals with many aspects of balance, or with things being out of balance.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A fair-minded person who can see multiple perspectives and judge impartially.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A trap, a Beast, a Construct, or an otherwise impartial foe.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where different forces exist in balance—such as a civilization in balance with nature, a land in balance with water, or chaos in balance with order.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure with value to two competing factions, or with two equal magical powers.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation where maintaining balance is important: keeping rivals satisfied, preserving the balance of power among different authorities, or rejecting false dichotomies and forced choices.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A judgmental or biased person willfully ignoring one perspective in favor of another.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Celestial, a Fiend, or some other creature strongly associated with a particular alignment or ideology.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where the balance of elemental or natural forces has been upset, with negative consequences.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure valuable only to certain people, or that can be used only in a very specific way.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Something being over- or undervalued.

card.name: Beast
entries: {@i The Beast card points to creatures of the animal kingdom and foul, cruel, or bad-tempered behavior in people.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who avoids the comforts of civilization or indulges predatory attitudes.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Beast, or a similar creature (such as a Fey or a Monstrosity) that is animal-like; alternatively, a pit or other confined space with a trapped animal within.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where animals roam freely.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that incorporates fur, feathers, bones, or claws from a Beast, or a magic item that allows transformation into a Beast (such as a {@item Cloak of the Bat} or {@item Staff of the Python}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving hunting animals or animals preying on people.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who fiercely represses urges they deem "bestial" in themselves or others.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A domesticated animal or a familiar.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where animals are contained, such as a farm or a zoo.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An ornate saddle, a goad, or another item related to the use of domestic animals, or a magic item that allows control of Beasts (such as a {@item Potion of Animal Friendship}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Domestic animals rebelling against people's control.

card.name: Book
entries: {@i An enormous book rests among scrolls and parchment, with a quill and ink nearby. The Book card embodies written information.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A writer, poet, or compulsive note-taker.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that keeps an exhaustive diary in some form, or that seeks a scribe to record its deeds.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A scriptorium or printing press.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable or magical pen, an ink vial, or a set of pigments (such as {@item Nolzur's Marvelous Pigments}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires gleaning information from written clues.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A well-educated person who reads often.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A trap involving written runes (such as a {@spell Glyph of Warding} or {@spell Symbol} spell).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A library or another storehouse of written knowledge.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable or magical written work, such as a book or scroll.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Secrets that should never have been discovered but were written down.

card.name: Bridge
entries: {@i A stone bridge arcs across a waterway. A shadowy figure lurks under the bridge, only its gleaming eyes clearly visible. This card reflects the effort required to overcome obstacles.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A mediator who enjoys helping others overcome misunderstandings or grievances.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: Someone who coordinates the efforts of different kinds of creatures, such as a {@creature mind flayer} mastermind using {@creature grimlock|MM|grimlocks} and {@creature troll|MM|trolls} as agents.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A bridge across a river or chasm.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting a bridge, or a magic item intended to help overcome obstacles (such as {@item Boots of Striding and Springing}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An urgent need for bridges between long-opposed factions.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who is part of a longstanding feud between two families or groups.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that lairs near, on, or under a bridge and either collects tolls from those using the bridge or tries to eat them.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A river or chasm with no bridge, or where the bridge is unsafe or has collapsed.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting walls, barriers. or a labyrinth; alternatively, a magic item that creates magical walls (such as a {@item Cube of Force}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Open conflict between two families or groups.

card.name: Campfire
entries: {@i A large campfire offers safety and comfort in the night. This card suggests a need for rest.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person on vacation, enjoying time away from work and pursuing activities they enjoy.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that alternates brief periods of activity with long periods of rest (as many reptiles and Dragons do); alternatively, a trap that requires a long time to reset between activations.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place recently used as a campsite.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting a peaceful scene, or a magic item that facilitates safe rest (such as a {@item Rod of Security}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A period of rest in the middle of a journey or an adventure.

items.name: Person
items.entry: An exhausted person.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature immune to {@condition exhaustion} (such as an angel, a golem, an Ooze, or an Undead), or a trap or hazard with a constant, ongoing effect.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere not conducive to rest, such as a busy marketplace active at all hours.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that suggests frenetic activity, or a magic item that helps its user remain alert (such as a {@item Sentinel Shield}),

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that demands unrelenting activity.

card.name: Cavern
entries: {@i A vast cavern is adorned with glowing fungi and striking stone formations. The Cavern card suggests exploration and delving into hidden secrets.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who asks probing questions but shares little.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature (such as a {@creature piercer} or a {@creature roper}) that mimics the features of natural caverns.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A cavern or a cavernous building such as a large temple.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A geode, jewelry made from gems and precious metals, or a magic item that grants {@sense darkvision} (such as {@item Goggles of Night}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires delving into hidden motivations and secrets.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who lives for the moment, avoiding introspection.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that swallows prey whole, or a trap that causes a ceiling or roof to collapse.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A small niche or cave.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that lacks a sense of depth or perspective.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Everyone's motivations exposed for all to see.

card.name: Celestial
entries: {@i A beautiful couatl twines through the clouds. This card suggests the involvement of celestial beings and service to the divine.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A devout person who looks for miracles and the presence of the divine in all parts of life.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Celestial or other creature that has connections to the gods, or a trap that deals radiant damage.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A location on the upper planes, or a place suffused with their influence.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting angels or other Celestials, treasure from the Upper Planes, or magic items made by Celestials.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Communication between the Upper Planes and the Material Plane—perhaps in dreams or visions, or with Celestials as intermediaries.

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone who carries a grudge over a real or perceived injury caused by a god or Celestial.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A fallen Celestial or similar creature that has lost its connection to the divine,

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place intended to ward off Celestials and influence from the Upper Planes.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure depicting a Celestial's fall, or a magic item useful against Celestials.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving Celestials' unwelcome interference in mortal affairs.

card.name: Comet
entries: {@i A comet with an enormous tail streaks across the winter sky at night, outshining the stars. The Comet card brings dire warnings or devastation.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A serious person with a gloomy outlook, perhaps carrying bad news.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature regarded as an ill omen, or signs that a dire creature approaches; alternatively, a trap marked by clear signs, perhaps surrounded by the corpses of its victims.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place with a connection to astronomical events: perhaps an observatory or a meteorite's crater.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that carries a curse, or one whose power is destined to be used for destructive ends.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A crisis about to spiral out of control.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who is grieving or delights in the suffering of others.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: The destruction left in the wake ofa rampaging creature, or smaller creatures fleeing from a larger one.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A ruin where a terrible event occurred in the past and that might now be haunted.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: . A treasure formed or shaped by disaster, bloodstained or haunted by former owners: alternatively, something good arising from a bad situation.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: The calm after a devastating storm: a situation where people are reeling from awful news or events.

card.name: Construct
entries: {@i A modron wields a wrench in the interior of a clockwork machine. This card signifies things made by hand, including Constructs.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An artisan who delights in handcrafted goods.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A construct, particularly designed to be animated (like a golem) as opposed to an ordinary object (like a {@creature animated broom|CM|broom} or {@creature rug of smothering|MM|rug}) that has been animated.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A workshop or art studio.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An exquisitely crafted art object (especially one with practical use) or magical tools.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An artisan attempting to bring a construct to life.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who scorns the idea of working with their hands.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature able to destroy buildings and objects, such as one with the Siege Monster trait.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A garbage heap or another place where objects are discarded.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An object fashioned with minimum alteration of its raw materials, or a magic item useful against Constructs (such as a {@item Mace of Smiting}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A rueful artisan attempting to destroy a Construct that has broken free of all restraint.

card.name: Corpse
entries: {@i An adventurer lies dead in a dungeon hallway, pierced by arrows. The Corpse card embodies decay and corruption.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An evil person whose morality has rotted away.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A zombie or similar corporeal Undead whose flesh is decaying, or a trapped corpse.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere things are left to rot, such as a graveyard or charnel house.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting dead bodies, a corpse just starting to decay, or a magic item that causes decay (such as a {@item Staff of Withering}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An organization or institution overwhelmed by corruption.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A good person who remains uncorrupted despite being surrounded by wickedness.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: An Ooze or fungus creature that facilitates the decomposition of corpses.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where fungus grows abundantly on a diet of rotting flesh.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that remains uncorrupted in the midst of rot.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An attempt to corrupt a respected and noble organization.

card.name: Crossroads
entries: {@i A signpost points in many directions at a crossroads. The Crossroads cards warns of a difficult but necessary decision.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person agonizing about a difficult decision or who regrets a recent decision.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that induces confusion or erratic behavior (such as an {@creature umber hulk}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A crossroads, or a settlement where trade routes cross.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that depicts a crossroads or cross patterns, or a magic item with multiple properties or uses (such as a staff).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A choice between options that are equally appealing—or equally disastrous.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who refuses to make decisions, relying instead on inaction or random determination.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that prevents others from acting (such as a {@creature ghoul}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place that constrains movement, such as a narrow ravine or passage.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object featuring overlapping circular patterns, or a magic item that does only does one thing a limited number of times (such as a wand).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation stemming from someone's refusal to act or choose.

card.name: Donjon
entries: {@i Underground stairs lead to a heavy door made of iron bars. This card represents both imprisonment and freedom.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A prisoner, or a person who feels trapped.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that grapples or swallows prey whole.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place of imprisonment, such as a literal dungeon or a menagerie.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure locked in a vault, or magic with the power to bind or imprison.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An impasse, a situation that threatens someone's freedom, or a situation where someone's indecision is keeping everyone in suspense.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A recently freed or escaped prisoner, or a free thinker who rejects social norms.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that has escaped from captivity or gone feral.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A prison broken open, or a place associated with liberation (such as a monument commemorating emancipation).

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that once held a being captive, such as an {@item Efreeti Bottle} that has lost its magic or an empty {@item Iron Flask}.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires creative solutions, or an effort to free people or creatures from captivity.

card.name: Door
entries: {@i A large wooden door bars the path ahead. The card offers an opportunity to change.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone trying to make amends for past misdeeds and adopt a better way of life.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that changes form, or a trapped door.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A door, an open doorway, or a passage from one place to another.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that looks very different from various perspectives, or a magic item that creates portals or allows teleportation (such as an {@item Amulet of the Planes}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An opportunity to deal with a situation differently than you have in the past.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who keeps repeating the same mistakes and misdeeds.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that causes its prey or enemies to change, such as a lycanthrope or slaad.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A locked door or barricaded passage.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A jeweled chest or lockbox, or a magic item that resists change (such as an {@item Immovable Rod}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that keeps recurring.

card.name: Dragon
entries: {@i A menacing red dragon perches atop its treasure hoard inside a cave. This card can point to things connected to Dragons, but it also suggests hoarding, reed, and places rich in magical energy.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A dragonborn, a person who uses draconic magic, a person who is fascinated by dragons, or a person who hoards wealth or other goods.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Dragon or similar creature.

items.name: Place
items.entry: The lair of a Dragon or some other impressive creature, or a site of great magical power.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: Large quantities of treasure, though not necessarily of great monetary value (for example, many copper coins or a large collection of cheap statuettes).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Someone hoarding resources that are widely needed or desired.

items.name: Person
items.entry: Someone with a grudge against a particular Dragon or against Dragons in general.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A dracolich or another Undead dragon, a Construct that resembles a Dragon, or another Dragon-like creature.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where a Dragon was slain, leaving a magical or physical scar on the land.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the death of a Dragon, or a magic item useful against Dragons (such as a {@item Dragon Slayer}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A group that plans to drive a Dragon from its lair, steal from its hoard, or kill it.

card.name: Elemental
entries: {@i A hungry Xorn feeds in an Underdark cavern. This card suggests an Elemental creature or reducing a thing to its essence.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who uses magic tied to the elements or who is cartoonishly two-dimensional.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: An Elemental creature, or a creature that uses air, earth, fire, or water magic.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place influenced by the Elemental Planes or associated with an element (such as a cave, a mountain, a volcano, or a river).

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that incorporates material from an Elemental Plane or imagery of the elements, or a magic item that conjures or controls Elementals (such as a {@item Ring of Elemental Command}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Forces from the Elemental Planes spilling into the world.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person driven by an internal conflict between two opposed tendencies or influences.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature (such as a mephit) that combines the substance of two Elemental Planes, or creatures from opposing Elemental Planes.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where forces of the Elemental Planes are in opposition to each other.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object that incorporates material from multiple Elemental Planes or imagery of elements in opposition; a magic item useful against Elementals.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Opposed forces from two or more Elemental Planes entering the world.

card.name: Euryale
entries: {@i A female medusa with a serpentine tail instead of legs is surrounded by flowers and herbs. The Euryale card points to vision, insight, and observation,}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who observes without becoming involved or attached,

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A {@creature medusa} or another creature with the power to petrify or a gaze attack.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere with commanding views, such as a watchtower or a high promontory.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A landscape painting or tapestry, or a magic item that enhances vision (such as {@item Goggles of Night}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that rewards or requires careful observation, such as a surveillance operation.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A nosy person vho inserts themself into situations where they don't belong.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature made of or associated with stone.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place with narrow windows (perhaps arrow slits) or with a limited view, perhaps underground.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A valuable sculpture or statue, a gemstone, or a magic item made from stone, such as a {@item Figurine of Wondrous Power}.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation arising from people's unwillingness to observe things as they are, or their tendency to project their own feelings and opinions onto others.

card.name: Expert
entries: {@i A bard plays a musical instrument. This card implies expertise, rightly or wrongly applied.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person (perhaps a bard, a rogue, a ranger, or an artificer) with exactly the right skills for the task at hand.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature with abilities similar to those of a bard, ranger, or rogue, such as expertise in one or more skills.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place (such as a guild hall) where skilled folk gather to share their expertise.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure with practical use, such as a musical instrument or a tool.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation that requires and rewards the expert application of practical skills.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who believes themself an expert but isn't actually helpful.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that relies on brute strength instead of skill or stealth.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place where children learn the basics of useful skills.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A wildly impractical treasure with no actual use, unwieldy to wear or display.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation stemming from someone's expertise being overlooked or ignored.

card.name: Fates
entries: {@i Three sisters weave, measure, and cut the threads of fate. This card explores the repercussions of decisions and reflects on the past.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person perhaps nearing the end of their life, troubled by past mistakes or reflecting on prior decisions.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A supernatural creature connected to fate, such as a Celestial, modron, or hag.

items.name: Place
items.entry: Somewhere meant for literal or metaphorical reflection, such as a room full of mirrors, a still mountain lake, a monastery, a hermitage, or a library.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An ornate or magical mirror, tapestry, or other woven treasure; alternatively, magic that can alter fate.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation ordained by fate, perhaps involving a supernatural punishment or reward.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person driven by the desire to escape whatever fate has in store.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature strongly associated with chaos, such as a demon or a slaad.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place that discourages reflection, such as a dark place or a noisy, busy one.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the effort to escape fate, or a magic item powered by chaos.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An unjust situation where evil is rewarded and good is punished.

card.name: Fey
entries: {@i A blink dog runs through the wild. When upright; this card can refer to a Fey creature or a sense of whimsy; reversed, it points to the gloomy Shadowfell.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person with Fey ancestry or some other connection to the Fey (such as a {@creature warlock of the Archfey|MPMM}), or a person with a whimsical sense of humor.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Fey creature, or some other creature with connections to the Feywild.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place in the Feywild, somewhere that allows passage to the Feywild, or a location where Fey magic is active.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting Fey or the Feywild, or a magic item made by Fey.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: An absurd situation that shouldn't be taken too seriously.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A gloomy person with no sense of humor, or a person who uses shadow-based magic.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature from the Shadowfell, or one transformed by shadow energy (such as a shadow dragon).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place in the Shadowfell, somewhere that allows passage to the Shadowfell, or a location where shadow magic is active.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting the Shadowfell, or a magic item that uses shadow magic.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A gloomy situation that offers little hope of success or escape.

card.name: Fiend
entries: {@i A balor strikes from the depths of the Abyss. This card alludes to an actual Fiend or the forces of the Lower Planes.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A tiefling, {@creature warlock of the Fiend|MPMM}, member of a Fiend-worshiping cult, or person who seeks to manipulate others into harmful contracts.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Fiend of any sort.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place on the Lower Planes, or a location suffused with their influence.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: An art object depicting Fiends, treasure from the Lower Planes, or magic items made by Fiends.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Interaction between the Lower Planes and the Material Plane perhaps an infernal bargain or demonic destruction.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who carries a grudge over a real or perceived injury caused by a Fiend, or a person trapped in a bargain with a Fiend.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A redeemed Fiend or similar creature that has lost its connection to the Lower Planes.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place intended to ward off Fiends and influence from the Lower Planes.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure depicting a Fiend's redemption, or a magic item useful against Fiends.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation involving Fiends' unwelcome interference in mortal affairs.

card.name: Flames
entries: {@i A chain devil, wreathed in flames, looks menacing and angry. The Flames card brings enemies and vengeance.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person carrying a bitter, possibly violent, grudge that poisons their outlook.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A Fiend, a vengeful Undead (such as a {@creature ghost} or {@creature revenant}), or a creature dedicated to pursuing designated prey (such as an {@creature invisible stalker}).

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place of bloodshed, or a place with a connection to the Lower Planes.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure that has been the subject of intense discord or rivalry, or a magic item originating on the Lower Planes.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A deep-seated enmity that clouds the judgment of those involved, or someone's thirst for revenge.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A person who is being hunted or persecuted unjustly.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature fleeing from a larger or more dangerous foe.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place of sanctuary for refugees and fugitives.

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A treasure symbolizing or commemorating the end of a feud or war, or a magic item that can charm or calm creatures (such as a {@item Rod of Rulership}).

items.name: Situation
items.entry: Unjust persecution or prejudicial hatred.

card.name: Fool
entries: {@i A person walks down a path, unwittingly dropping items along the way. The Fool card represents innocence.}

items.name: Person
items.entry: An innocent or naive person blissfully ignorant of the world's sinister side, possibly a child.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A naive Celestial or a flighty Fey, or a trap with a simple or obvious means of avoiding it.

items.name: Place
items.entry: A place connected with children, such as a nursery, an orphanage, or a school.s

items.name: Treasure
items.entry: A portrait of a child, jewelry meant for a child, or a magic item connected to the Upper Planes.

items.name: Situation
items.entry: A situation requiring trust, honesty, and a leap of faith.

items.name: Person
items.entry: A con artist who preys on the innocent and gullible while presenting a trustworthy facade.

items.name: Creature or Trap
items.entry: A creature that changes shape to appear harmless so it can get close to its prey, or a trap that is difficult to avoid.

items.name: Place
